Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Using Stable Isotopes to Constrain the Atmospheric Carbon Monoxide Budget over the Last 20,000 Years
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mak/1443482

This project will compare current atmospheric conditions with those of the remote past prior to human influence. This is important in order to understand the impact of human activities on Earth's atmosphere, and to determine the stability of the composition of the atmosphere in the past. How humans have impacted Earth?s atmospheric composition is important for developing accurate predictions of future global atmospheric conditions. In addition to training students, the investigators will support continuing education of high school science teachers on Long Island through specifically tailored, interactive seminars on various topics in earth science, atmospheric sciences, physics and biology. A pilot program at Mount Sinai School District, near Stony Brook University will be the first implementation of this program.

The investigators plan to reconstruct historical variations in the sources of atmospheric carbon monoxide (CO) from measurements of the concentration and stable isotopic abundance of carbon monoxide ([CO], 13CO and C18O) in the South Pole Ice Core, which is being drilled in 2014-2016. The goal is to strategically sample and reconstruct the relative variations in CO source strengths over the past 20,000 years. These will be the first measurements to extend the CO record beyond 650 years before present, back to the last glacial maximum. Both atmospheric chemical processes and variations in CO sources can impact the CO budget, and variations in the CO budget are useful in identifying and quantifying chemistry-climate interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon monoxide is an important gas in the chemistry of the global atmosphere. Reaction with carbon monoxide is the main removal mechanism for hydroxyl radicals (OH) in unpolluted air. OH is in turn the main "detergent" of the atmosphere, removing many greenhouse gases and other trace gases / pollutants. Changes in atmospheric carbon monoxide through time before the industrial era are therefore important for understanding natural changes in atmospheric chemistry. One of the main natural sources of carbon monoxide to the atmosphere is emission from wildfires ("biomass burning"). Biomass burning is an important part of the global carbon cycle and a source of particulates that interact with solar radiation via absorption (warming effect) or scattering (cooling effect). Carbon monoxide variations can help to identify changes in the intensity of biomass burning through time. Stable isotope ratios in atmospheric carbon monoxide (13C / 12C and 18O/16O) provide added power for understanding the causes of carbon monoxide variations, allowing to distinguish between processed such as diminished biomass burning emissions and increased carbon monoxide removal by reaction with OH.

The main aim of this project was to improve understanding of changes in atmospheric carbon monoxide during the last deglaciation (≈10 – 20 thousand years ago) by making measurements of carbon monoxide concentration and stable isotopes in ancient air from ≈50 glacial ice samples from the South Pole ice core. This is a formidable analytical challenge, as we are working with nanogram-size samples, with multiple potential sources of procedural interference / isotopic fractionation / contamination.

Project progress was slowed considerably for a number of reasons. First, the original plan was to make the measurements using a system at the University of Colorado that was capable of analyzing carbon monoxide stable isotopes in small air samples, but needed further development to enable ice core measurements (which require extraction of trapped air from the ice by melting). However, near the start of the project the Colorado lab moved to a new space that was no longer suitable for further development of this system. It was therefore decided to make the measurements at the University of Rochester, where the entire analytical system had to be developed mainly from scratch. The main focus of the project therefore shifted to system development. Multiple other issues continued to slow progress, including poor workmanship on some of the purchased system glass components (resulting in small but problematic leaks that were difficult to diagnose), unanticipated issues involving gas handling (such as unexpected break-through or trapping and re-release of certain gases on cryogenic traps), instrument malfunctions (mass spectrometer and reducing gas detector) as well as a COVID-related multi-month shutdown of the Rochester laboratory.

At the time of writing of this report, the new ice core carbon monoxide stable isotope system at U Rochester is close to completion. Once completed, this would be one of only two systems in the world capable of such analyses. The system is fully suitable / has been demonstrated to work well for analyses of small air samples. The system has also been demonstrated to work well / with a low and consistent blank for analyses of carbon monoxide concentrations from ice samples using a melting technique. One difficult-to-diagnose analytical issue remains (involving an air impurity in the final sample for isotope analysis, but no apparent air leaks). Because of this, measurements of the South Pole samples have not yet been completed, as the precious samples must be preserved until the system has been fully demonstrated to perform well. As the goals of this project align well with goals of some of the other projects in the U Rochester lab, it is anticipated that system development will continue to completion and sample analyses will proceed in the next year.

This project contributed to the comprehensive training of two PhD students in relevant analytical techniques, analytical system design and construction, troubleshooting as well as data analysis, interpretation, presentation and scientific writing. 

Results of the work to date (focused on analytical system development) have been shared with the scientific community at several professional conferences and workshops. The project also included active communication with / educating the public about the nature of our work. This included public lectures, school visits, interviews on the local public radio station, an "ask a scientist" table at a local farmers market, as well as an educational blog about polar fieldwork.
